pullRequest.body:
These theorems give that if A is a unit, or a unitary, in the n x n matrices over a commutative ring R, and B is an m x n matrix over R, that multiplying B by A on the left or right doesn't change the rank of B. To facilitate this, added `isUnits_det_units` and `det_isUnit` lemmas.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: How would `simp` actually apply the `IsUnit` version? I didn't think this problem is specific to matrices at all.

> How would `simp` actually apply the `IsUnit` version?

`simp` would automatically solve any side-goals of the form `IsUnit (Units.val u)`, since the unit-ness is structural.

@eric-wieser ha! I didn't know that worked. This wasn't available in Lean 3, was it?

I *think* in the `Matrix` library we phrase things in terms of `IsUnit (det A)` instead of `IsUnit A` almost all the time. At the same time, I don't think we actually want [`Matrix.isUnit_iff_isUnit_det`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/Matrix/NonsingularInverse.html#Matrix.isUnit_iff_isUnit_det) to be a `simp` lemma.

One thing we could do: mark `rank_mul_eq_right_of_isUnit_det` and similar as `@[simp]`, and then add `simp` lemmas, which then allow these to trigger.

```lean
import Mathlib

-- some hypotheses too strong maybe
variable {m n R : Type*} [Fintype n] [CommRing R] [StarRing R] [DecidableEq n]
namespace Matrix

@[simp]
lemma isUnit_det_units (A : (Matrix n n R)Ë£) : IsUnit (det (A : Matrix n n R)) :=
  A.isUnit.map detMonoidHom

@[simp]
lemma isUnit_det_unitaryGroup (A : unitaryGroup n R) : IsUnit (det (A : Matrix n n R)) :=
  (unitary.toUnits A).isUnit.map detMonoidHom

attribute [simp] rank_mul_eq_left_of_isUnit_det rank_mul_eq_right_of_isUnit_det
  isUnit_det_of_invertible

-- then the following work `by simp`

theorem rank_mul_unitary (A : unitaryGroup n R) (B : Matrix m n R) :
    rank (B * (A : Matrix n n R)) = rank B := by
  simp? -- simp only [isUnit_det_unitaryGroup, rank_mul_eq_left_of_isUnit_det]

theorem rank_unitary_mul [Fintype m] (A : unitaryGroup n R)
    (B : Matrix n m R) : rank ((A : Matrix n n R) * B) = rank B := by
  simp? -- simp only [isUnit_det_unitaryGroup, rank_mul_eq_right_of_isUnit_det]

end Matrix
```

@eric-wieser I've implemented the change I posted above. Even if we decide that we want to refactor the matrix library and how we handle invertibility, it shouldn't be part of this PR. But now I've rewritten the content of this PR, so I shouldn't merge it.
!bench

:v: JonBannon can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/8b89c56d-1069-408d-8287-da5011f6c97d) for commit a3f60b1e66caa5cdb7ed123682ce3992864cb919.
There were [no significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/2e478d48-2aa7-40c5-a708-fafa416b9a78/to/8b89c56d-1069-408d-8287-da5011f6c97d) against commit e8433a6b8e7980bfaaf9b34513b77da2af14995a.
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8914871962/job/24483365510)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8914871962/job/24483365923)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/8914871962/job/24483366212)

Thanks, this looks good now. Let's check there's no major performance regression.

Can you check the PR description is up to date with the new version?

bors d+

I'm a little sad that this API has to exist. The problem seems to be that we don't have a standard way to talk about whether a matrix is invertible, and so we end up writing lemmas for every possible way we might want to write it (`IsUnit M`, `IsUnit M.det`, `M : Units (Matrix _ _ _)`, `Invertible M`).

If we declared `IsUnit M` the simp-normal form of `IsUnit M.det` (or possibly vice-versa), then we could mark `Units.isUnit` `simp` and we probably wouldn't need these new lemmas.

Thanks, this looks good now. Let's check there's no major performance regression.

Can you check the PR description is up to date with the new version?

bors d+
It's not necessary to shadow all of these variables since most (all?) are in context already. Any variables that are still needed should be put directly in the theorem statement.
OK. Will do. I ended up doing this in the unitary part because some things broke when I tried to include this...
Ok made the changes. I had to keep the [DecidableEq n] for each of these, but otherwise everything was already there.
I understand that these can't go into an earlier file for import reasons, but they don't belong this far down the file. Please make a short section at the beginning of the file for these two.
Right at the beginning?
yes.
I created a section for this near the beginning.

```suggestion
theorem rank_unitary_mul (A : unitaryGroup n R) (B : Matrix m n R) :
```

style, note that you were missing spaces, but also the line break locations were a bit weird.
```suggestion
theorem rank_mul_unitary [CommRing R] [Fintype m] [StarRing R] (A : unitaryGroup n R)
    (B : Matrix n m R) : rank ((A : Matrix n n R) * B) = rank B :=
```

It's easy to catch random changes like this by looking at the diff. We try to keep the diff as small as possible.
```suggestion
```

Only one line between declarations, per the [style guide](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html)
```suggestion
```

Can you please move this section up even higher? For instance, ever before the first `variable` declaration? The issue is that, as written, it leads to a fairly arbitrary hypothesis order for the these declarations:
```
{n : Type*} [Fintype n] [DecidableEq n] {m R : Type*} [CommRing R] [StarRing R]
```
It probably makes more sense to just have a section at the very beginning with `variable {m n R : Type*} ...`
OK. Done.

As written, this runs the risk of having *duplicate* `[CommRing R]` and `[StarRing R]` hypotheses in the statement, since these were already declared with `variable`.
```suggestion
theorem rank_mul_unitary [Fintype m] (A : unitaryGroup n R)
```

```suggestion
theorem rank_mul_unitary (A : unitaryGroup n R) (B : Matrix m n R) :
```

```suggestion
theorem rank_unitary_mul [Fintype m] (A : unitaryGroup n R)
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: make `rank_mul_eq_left_of_isUnit_det` into an effective `simp` lemma

nodes.body:
I'm a little sad that this API has to exist. The problem seems to be that we don't have a standard way to talk about whether a matrix is invertible, and so we end up writing lemmas for every possible way we might want to write it (`IsUnit M`, `IsUnit M.det`, `M : Units (Matrix _ _ _)`, `Invertible M`).

If we declared `IsUnit M` the simp-normal form of `IsUnit M.det` (or possibly vice-versa), then we could mark `Units.isUnit` `simp` and we probably wouldn't need these new lemmas.
How would `simp` actually apply the `IsUnit` version? I didn't think this problem is specific to matrices at all.

> How would `simp` actually apply the `IsUnit` version?

`simp` would automatically solve any side-goals of the form `IsUnit (Units.val u)`, since the unit-ness is structural.

@eric-wieser ha! I didn't know that worked. This wasn't available in Lean 3, was it?

I *think* in the `Matrix` library we phrase things in terms of `IsUnit (det A)` instead of `IsUnit A` almost all the time. At the same time, I don't think we actually want [`Matrix.isUnit_iff_isUnit_det`](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/Matrix/NonsingularInverse.html#Matrix.isUnit_iff_isUnit_det) to be a `simp` lemma.

One thing we could do: mark `rank_mul_eq_right_of_isUnit_det` and similar as `@[simp]`, and then add `simp` lemmas, which then allow these to trigger.

```lean
import Mathlib

-- some hypotheses too strong maybe
variable {m n R : Type*} [Fintype n] [CommRing R] [StarRing R] [DecidableEq n]
namespace Matrix

@[simp]
lemma isUnit_det_units (A : (Matrix n n R)Ë£) : IsUnit (det (A : Matrix n n R)) :=
  A.isUnit.map detMonoidHom

@[simp]
lemma isUnit_det_unitaryGroup (A : unitaryGroup n R) : IsUnit (det (A : Matrix n n R)) :=
  (unitary.toUnits A).isUnit.map detMonoidHom

attribute [simp] rank_mul_eq_left_of_isUnit_det rank_mul_eq_right_of_isUnit_det
  isUnit_det_of_invertible

-- then the following work `by simp`

theorem rank_mul_unitary (A : unitaryGroup n R) (B : Matrix m n R) :
    rank (B * (A : Matrix n n R)) = rank B := by
  simp? -- simp only [isUnit_det_unitaryGroup, rank_mul_eq_left_of_isUnit_det]

theorem rank_unitary_mul [Fintype m] (A : unitaryGroup n R)
    (B : Matrix n m R) : rank ((A : Matrix n n R) * B) = rank B := by
  simp? -- simp only [isUnit_det_unitaryGroup, rank_mul_eq_right_of_isUnit_det]

end Matrix
```

@eric-wieser I've implemented the change I posted above. Even if we decide that we want to refactor the matrix library and how we handle invertibility, it shouldn't be part of this PR. But now I've rewritten the content of this PR, so I shouldn't merge it.
